questions.text: 1. Identify the manoeuvre shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The maneuver shown in the image is Lovset's maneuver, used for the delivery of extended arms in breech presentation.

The principle of this maneuver is based on the curved birth canal. The shoulder placement favorable for this maneuver is:

* anterior shoulder - above the symphysis pubis

* posterior shoulder - below the sacral promontory.

Rotating the trunk while keeping the back anterior and applying downward traction brings the posterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis.

The technique followed in Lovset's maneuver is 

* The baby is grasped with both hands using a femoropelvic grip, keeping the thumbs parallel to the vertebral column. The maneuver should start only when the inferior angle of the anterior scapula is visible underneath the pubic arch.

* The baby is lifted slightly to cause lateral flexion. The trunk is rotated 180°, keeping the back anterior and maintaining downward traction.

* The trunk is then rotated in the reverse direction, keeping the back anterior, to deliver the former anterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis.

Lovset's maneuver can be employed in all types of arm displacement. It does not involve any intrauterine manipulation. These factors make it a preferred maneuver.

Pearl PM1839: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

* Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa

* Catch hold of the ankle

* Pull down along with abduction



 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

* Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.

* Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.

* Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 



 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

* Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.

* Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.



 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

* Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.

* When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.

* Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.



 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

* Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.

* Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.

* Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.

* Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.

* Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.



 

Mnemonic:

* Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)

* Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: 2. The hysterectomy specimen of a 65 year old patient is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this 65-year-old woman’s hysterectomy specimen is endometrial carcinoma.

In elderly, postmenopausal women, an irregular, friable growth filling the endometrial cavity with myometrial invasion strongly suggests endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial cancer may be localised or diffuse. It may appear as a nodule, polyp or diffuse lesion involving the entire uterine cavity. The risk factors include PCOS, HRT, obesity, hypertension and diabetes. 

About 7-10% cases are asymptomatic. Other clinical features include:

* Postmenopausal bleeding/discharge (most common)

* Menorrhagia or irregular periods in perimenopausal women

* Late features include pain and an abdominal lump

* On per vaginal exam, the uterus may be normal or bulky (due to tumour, fibroid, or pyometra)

* An adnexal mass may be present, usually feminizing ovarian tumour or metastasis

* Advanced disease presents as bulky cervix, patulous os, growth protruding through os

* Vaginal or suburethral metastatic nodules can rarely be present

Other options: 

Option A: Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrium in the walls of the uterus. The uterus appears symmetrically enlarged to not more than 14 weeks size. The cut section may show only a localized nodular enlargement. Most of the time, the affected area reveals a peculiar, diffuse, striated and noncapsulated involvement of the myometrium with tiny dark haemorrhagic areas in between. 

The hysterectomy specimen of adenomyosis is shown below:



Option C: Endometriosis refers to endometrium outside the endometrial lining(such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, or peritoneum), which causes chronic pelvic pain, menstrual irregularity and infertility. It does not involve the endometrium itself in hysterectomy specimens.

Option D: Fibroid (leiomyoma) is a benign smooth muscle tumour of the uterus that presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass with a whorled appearance and a pseudocapsule, rather than irregular endometrial masses. An image of gross specimen of fibroid uterus is given below:



Pearl PM2176: Types of endometrial carcinoma

Characteristics Type 1 Type 2
Age 55–65 yr 65–75 yr
Clinical setting Unopposed estrogen
Obesity
Hypertension
Diabetes		 Atrophy
Thin physique
Morphology Endometrioid Serous
Clear Cell
Mixed mullerian tumor
Precursor Atypical hyperplasia Serous endometrial
intraepithelial carcinoma

Mutated genes/genetic 

abnormalities

 PTEN
ARID1A (regulator of chromatin)
PIK3CA (PI3K)
KRAS
FGF2 (growth factor)
MSI
CTNNB1 (Wnt signaling)
TP53		 TP53
Aneuploidy
PIK3CA (PI3K)
FBXW7 (regulator of MYC, cyclin E)
CHD4 (regulator of chromatin)
PPP2R1A (PP2A)
Behavior Indolent
Spreads via lymphatics		 Aggressive
Intraperitoneal and
lymphatic spread


Pearl PM1377: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

questions.text: 3. A 55-year post-menopausal woman presents to the OPD for a routine BP checkup. Her BP was 170/100 mm Hg. She also complains of bloodstained discharge per vagina. What is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Reassure her that some discharge is normal at this age
Immediate pelvic examination, TVS and pap smear
Immediate referral to a cardiologist to control BP

questions.solution:
The next best step of management is immediate pelvic examination, TVS and pap smear. 

A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presenting with blood-stained vaginal discharge should be thoroughly evaluated to rule out endometrial hyperplasia and malignancy of the genital tract. Additionally, her hypertension (BP 170/100 mm Hg) is a recognised risk factor for endometrial carcinoma. Other risk factors include obesity, diabetes, polycystic ovarian syndrome, older age, early age of menarche, late age of menopause, nulliparity, and long-term contraceptive use. 

As part of the evaluation, a pelvic examination is performed, which may reveal any abnormality in the lower genital tract such as an enlarged uterus, abnormal cervix or adnexal mass. Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is performed to assess endometrial thickness and detect any endometrial pathology like an endometrial polyp. An endometrial thickness of more than 4 mm indicates the need of endometrial biopsy. A Pap smear is done to screen for cervical abnormalities and exclude cervical cancer.



Other options:

Option A: Reassurance is not appropriate because postmenopausal bleeding is never normal.

Option C: Referral to a cardiologist is also not the immediate step, as her blood pressure, though high, is not an acute emergency in this setting.

Option D: Proceeding directly to hysterectomy without confirming the diagnosis is incorrect. The appropriate next step is to establish the cause of post-menopausal bleeding and exclude malignancy.

questions.text: 4. A 32-year-old with gestational diabetes mellitus and fetal macrosomia is in labour, the head is delivered, but the shoulders are stuck even after 1 minute. What is the sequence of manoeuvres?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a delay in delivery of the baby's shoulders for more than 1 minute after delivery of the head indicates shoulder dystocia, and the correct sequence for managing shoulder dystocia is: McRobert’s manoeuvre → Rubin manoeuvre → Gaskin manoeuvre → Zavanelli manoeuvre.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal pelvis or on the sacral promontory. The diagnosis is made on the basis of:

* Definite recoil of the head back against the perineum (turtle neck sign)

* Failure of spontaneous restitution of fetal head

* Fetal face becomes plethoric

* Failure of shoulder to descend

Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia:

*

McRoberts Maneuver: Abduct and sharply flex the maternal thighs onto the abdomen, which straightens the lumbosacral angle, rotates the pelvis, frees the impacted shoulder, and increases the available space (image below). Along with this maneuver, suprapubic pressure is applied, which directs the fetal head posteriorly to reduce the shoulder diameter and rotate it into the oblique plane.



* Rubin’s Maneuver: Rotate the easily accessible fetal shoulder, usually the posterior shoulder, to help release the impacted shoulder (image below).



* Woods Corkscrew Maneuver: Rotate the posterior shoulder 180° in a corkscrew fashion to align it for delivery (image below).



* Extraction of the posterior arm is done with the help of Jacquemier maneuver.

*

Gaskin Maneuver: Place the mother on her hands and knees (all fours position) to increase pelvic dimensions and allow downward traction on the posterior shoulder to free it.

* If other measures fail, the fetus can be pushed back into the uterus for cesarean delivery (Zavanelli manoeuvre), the clavicle can be fractured to reduce shoulder girth (cleidotomy), or, rarely, symphysiotomy may be performed. The images showing Zavanelli manoeuvre and cleidotomy is shown below:

questions.text: 5. A primigravida at 37 weeks presents with decreased foetal movements for 1 day. NST showed one acceleration in 20 minutes and no decelerations. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step is to continue NST for 40 minutes. 

At 37 weeks, a non-stress test (NST) with only one acceleration in 20 minutes is considered non-reactive. However, before confirming any abnormality, the NST should be extended to 40 minutes. 

In non-stress test (NST), a continuous electronic monitoring of the fetal heart rate along with recording of fetal movements (cardiotocography) is undertaken. There is an observed association of FHR acceleration with fetal movements, which when present, indicates a healthy fetus. 

When two or more accelerations of more than 15 beats per minute above the baseline and longer than 15 seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation, it is intrepreted as reactive. On the other hand, a nonreactive NST is not always ominous and can be seen with a sleeping fetus. Hence, before concluding that a test is nonreactive, a 40 minute or longer tracing should be performed.

Other options:

Option A: Induction of labour is not indicated at this stage because the NST has not yet been confirmed abnormal. Reactivity may still occur with extended monitoring.

Option C: Emergency LSCS is indicated only if there is clear evidence of acute fetal distress, which is not present here. 

Option D: Instrumental delivery applies when the woman is in the second stage of labour. This patient is not in labour, so it’s not appropriate.

questions.text: 6. A 25 year-old female has regular 28-day cycles. Which of these hormonal patterns will be seen during day 21-25 of her cycle?

choices.text: Increased estrogen, decreased progesterone, low LH, high FSH
Decreased estrogen and increased progesterone, high FSH and low LH
Increased estrogen and progesterone, low FSH and LH
Decreased estrogen and increased progesterone, low FSH and LH

questions.solution:
During days 21-25 of her menstrual cycle that is, during the luteal phase, there will be increased estrogen and progesterone and low FSH and LH.

The menstrual cycle is characterized by distinct hormonal changes across its different phases:

* In the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle, the endometrium is under the control of oestrogen. The Graafian follicle secretes 17-β-oestradiol, which produces proliferative changes in the endometrium. This oestrogen produces proliferative changes in the endometrium, secretes inhibin which inhibits further secretion of FSH, and stimulates LH receptors in the theca cells while also stimulating the anterior pituitary to secrete LH.

* At ovulation (which occurs around day 14), the maximum peak of oestrogen secretion is seen about 48 hours before ovulation, whereas the LH surge occurs about 24–36 hours before ovulation. LH causes rupture of the follicle and formation of the corpus luteum.

* In the luteal phase (in this case), the ruptured follicle forms the corpus luteum, which secretes progesterone. As a result, progesterone levels rise markedly, while oestrogen is also moderately increased. These high levels exert negative feedback, so FSH and LH remain low.

* In the menstrual phase, in the absence of pregnancy, the corpus luteum regresses, leading to a decline in both oestrogen and progesterone levels. This fall removes the negative feedback, and gonadotropins begins to rise again, initiating recruitment of new follicles for the next cycle.

questions.text: 7. A 65-year-old woman presented with abdominal swelling and discomfort. Ultrasonography showed ascites and a multiloculated, predominantly cystic swelling with papillary projections. CA-125 was 1035IU/mL. The gross image of the resected mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is serous cystadenocarcinoma, a common epithelial ovarian cancer seen in postmenopausal women.

This patient’s presentation with abdominal swelling, ascites, ultrasonography showing a multiloculated cystic mass with papillary projections and the gross image showing a large, multilocular cystic mass is most suggestive of serous cystadenocarcinoma. The markedly elevated CA-125 level (1035 IU/mL) further supports the diagnosis, as this tumour marker is typically raised in epithelial ovarian cancers like the serous type. 

Other options: 

Option A: Granulosa cell tumor are sex cord-stromal tumors that are hormonally active and often produce estrogen, leading to symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding or endometrial hyperplasia, which are not seen in this patient. Additionally, granulosa cell tumors rarely cause massive ascites, and they typically secrete inhibin, which is a marker for this tumour.

Option B: Sertoli–Leydig cell tumour are rare ovarian tumours that are androgen-producing, which causes defeminization followed by masculinization. They usually present with features such as flattening of breasts, amenorrhea, hirsutism, enlargement of the clitoris, and even breaking of the voice. Imaging often shows a gross appearance like that of other mesenchymomas, and CA-125 is usually not markedly elevated.

Option C: Immature teratoma is a rare tumour containing elements from multiple germ layers. They are mostly solid tumours with a trabeculated appearance. The solid part of the tumour contains cartilage, bone, and muscle, whereas hair and sebaceous material are found in the cystic spaces. A rudimentary eye can also be seen. They are generally malignant, whereas mature teratomas like dermoid cysts are benign. They are not commonly associated with papillary projections, massive ascites, or markedly raised CA-125, which are hallmarks of epithelial ovarian cancers like serous cystadenocarcinoma.

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right).



Pearl PM1433: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

* Serous tumors

* Mucinous tumors

* Endometrioid tumors

* Clear cell 

* Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)

* Seromucinous

* Undifferentiated carcinoma

II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

* Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor

* Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor

* Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

* Dysgerminoma

* Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Polyembryoma

* Non-gestational choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma (Mature/immature)

* Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

* Pure

* Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary VI. Miscellaneous tumors VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors VIII. Tumor-like conditions

Pearl PM1872: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell


Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

* D: Dysgerminoma

* P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)

* L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: 8. A primigravida suffers atonic postpartum haemorrhage during labour. After initial measures and medical management failed, what is the next best step of management that can be done in the labour room?
questions.solution:
In a primigravida with atonic PPH where initial measures like uterine massage and medical management have failed, the next best step of management that can be done in the labour room is balloon tamponade.

For balloon tamponade, Foley catheter, Bakri balloon, Condom catheter or Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is inserted into the uterine cavity and the balloon is inflated with normal saline (200-500 mL). It reduces PPH by stimulating uterine contraction and exerting direct hemostatic pressure (tamponade effect) to the open uterine sinuses. It is kept for 4-6 hours. This can avoid hysterectomy in most cases.

The given image shows Bakri balloon tamponade:





The following are the steps used in controlling postpartum haemorrhage:

* Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.

* In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine. 

* If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done for removing any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued. Other uterotonic agents can also be given.

* Uterine massage and bimanual compression

* Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade)

* Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:

* Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture

* Ligation of uterine arteries

* Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis

* Ligation of internal iliac artery

* Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel

*   Hysterectomy

questions.text: 9. A G2P1L1 suffers cord prolapse during labour. Cervix was 5cm dilated and cord pulsations were present. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Elevate buttocks, tilt head back and fill bladder
Push the cord back into the vagina and pack

questions.solution:
The best step in management of cord prolapse with pulsations present is to relieve pressure on the cord immediately. This is done by elevating the buttocks and tilting head back (trendelenberg position), and filling the bladder with fluid. These measures lift the presenting part off the cord and improve blood flow.

Vago's method is used in cord prolapse to alleviate pressure on the cord. Vagos method is also known as the bladder-filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

* Living or dead baby

* Viability of the baby

* Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

* If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 

* When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances, as it takes a longer time 

* Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction

* Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction

*

When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible:

* Oxytocin infusion is stopped

* IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring

* Relieve pressure on the cord by:

* Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina.

* Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position.

* Vagos method: Foley catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression of the cord.

* Funic reduction: Gentle manual repositioning of the cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.

* Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

* If the baby is dead -

*

* Reconfirmation with ultrasound

* Spontaneous delivery when death is confirmed

* Destructive operations are rarely needed

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is given below:



Other options:

Option B: Wait and watch is not an option because ongoing compression can quickly lead to fetal hypoxia and death.

Option C: Oxytocin to accelerate delivery is not useful at 5 cm dilation because vaginal delivery will not happen immediately. The baby will not be delivered fast enough to prevent damage.

Option D: Pushing the cord back and packing is avoided as it may increase trauma and worsen compression, leading to more harm.

questions.text: 10. What is the order of closure in a mediolateral episiotomy?
questions.solution:
The correct order of closure in a mediolateral episiotomy is Mucosa → Muscle → Skin.

The repair of a mediolateral episiotomy is done in three layers. The repair is to be done in the following order

* Vaginal mucosa and submucosal tissues

* Perineal muscles

* Skin and subcutaneous tissues

The vaginal mucosa is sutured first. The apex of the episiotomy is identified, and an anchor stitch is placed. Thereafter, the vaginal walls are apposed by interrupted sutures with polyglycolic acid suture or chromic catgut, from above downwards till the fourchette is reached. A continuous suture may cause puckering and shortening of the posterior vaginal wall. Care should be taken not to injure the rectum. 

The principles to be followed are: 

* Perfect hemostasis

* To obliterate the dead space

* Suture without tension

 However, routine episiotomy is not recommended for the management of the 2nd stage of labour. The indications of an episiotomy are:

* Rigid inelastic perineum causing arrest or delay in descent of the presenting part as in elderly primigravidae

* Anticipating perineal tear due to a big baby, face-to-pubis delivery, breech delivery, shoulder dystocia, and persistent occiput posterior

* Operative delivery, like forceps delivery and ventouse delivery

* Previous perineal surgery, like pelvic floor repair and perineal reconstructive surgery

The image below shows the episiotomy scissors:



Pearl PM0044: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

* Posterior vaginal wall

* Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani

* Fascia covering those muscles

* Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves

* Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: 11. A patient presents with 2 months of amenorrhea with enlarged uterus. On examination, there is darkening of areola, prominent Montgomery tubercles, linea nigra is present and there is bluish discolouration of the vagina on PV. How would you categorise these signs in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings are categorised as probable signs of pregnancy.

The patient shows amenorrhea, breast changes (like darkened areola and Montgomery tubercles), linea nigra, and Chadwick’s sign, which are presumptive signs of pregnancy. However, the patient also has uterine enlargement, which is an objective physical change of the uterus and is classified as a probable sign of pregnancy, because it is detectable by the clinician. Although most features are presumptive, the presence of uterine enlargement, which is a probable sign, makes the overall signs of pregnancy beyond purely presumptive, and this patient’s findings can be categorised as probable signs of pregnancy.

The signs and symptoms of pregnancy can be categorised into: 

* Presumptive signs: These are primarily the features appreciated by the woman and include amenorrhea, frequency of micturition, morning sickness, fatigue, breast changes, skin pigmentation (like linea nigra and chloasma), quickening.

* Probable signs: These are mainly detectable physical changes in the uterus observed by the clinician. They include uterine enlargement, changes in shape and consistency of the uterus, Hegar’s sign (softening of the lower uterine segment), Jacquemier’s sign, ballottement, and immunological tests.

* Positive (absolute) signs: These are absolute indicators of pregnancy and include palpation of fetal parts, perception of fetal movements by the examiner, auscultation of fetal heart sounds, and ultrasound detection of the gestational sac or embryo. These signs confirm pregnancy beyond doubt.

Other options:

Option D:  In pseudopregnancy, there is no true pregnancy. It is also called as pseudocyesis, which is a psychological disorder where the woman has the false but firm belief that she is pregnant, although no pregnancy exists. The conspicuous feature is cessation of menstruation. Obstetric examination often excludes pregnancy. Examination with ultrasound and immunological tests for pregnancy is done to exclude pregnancy.

Pearl PM1824: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: 12. A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presented with secondary amenorrhoea for 1 year. She had elevated gonadotropic hormones (FSH 36 IU/L, LH 56 IU/L) and decreased AMH (0.05 ng). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is premature ovarian insufficiency, because the patient has secondary amenorrhoea with high FSH and LH (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism) and very low AMH, indicating depleted ovarian reserve.

Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) is defined as loss of oocytes and the surrounding support cells prior to age 40 years. The diagnosis is determined by two serum FSH levels that measure greater than a threshold range of 30 to 40 mIU/mL and are obtained at least 1 month apart. This definition distinguishes POI from the physiologic loss of ovarian function, which occurs with normal menopause.

AMH is secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testis and granulosa cells in the ovary. In males, it inhibits the development of the Mullerian system and its absence can result in hermaphroditism. In the female, it helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation.

The estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in an infertile woman and a woman with secondary amenorrhoea. They strongly correlate with the number of ovarian primordial follicles. This makes AMH the best predictor for measuring ovarian reserve. The AMH values and their interpretation are given below:

* Normal value: 2–6.8 ng/mL

* Poor ovarian reserve : <1 ng/mL

* PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome: >10 ng/mL

The other indicator of ovarian reserve is FSH levels measured in the early follicular phase (between day 2 and day 4 of the menstrual cycle). A value of >10 mIU/mL may indicate significant loss of ovarian reserve.

Other options:

Option A: PCOS typically shows LH levels raised over 10 IU/mL and normal FSH, hence ruling it out.

Option B: Hyperprolactinaemia would cause amenorrhoea, but usually with high prolactin and suppressed gonadotropins, not elevated FSH/LH.

Option C: Hyperthyroidism can cause menstrual irregularity, but would not explain high FSH/LH with low AMH.

questions.text: 13. A primigravida was prescribed Pritchard's regimen to manage pre-eclampsia. What is the total loading dose of magnesium sulphate given?
questions.solution:
14 g is the total loading dose of magnesium sulphate given in Pritchard's regimen to manage pre-eclampsia.

Magnesium sulphate is used to manage severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia. It acts as a membrane stabilizer and neuroprotector. It also reduces motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine and blocks neuronal calcium influx.

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion


Repeat injections are given only if the knee jerks are present, urine output exceeds 30 mL/h and the respiration rate is more than 12/minute. The therapeutic level of serum magnesium is 4-7 mEq/L.

Magnesium sulphate is continued for 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery, whichever is later. For recurrence of fits, a further 2 g IV bolus is given over 5 minutes in the above regimens. If the patient seizes, despite magnesium therapy, midazolam 1-2 mg IV is given. 

Magnesium toxicity manifests as loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, altered cardiac conduction and cardiac arrest. Calcium gluconate is the antidote to cardiac toxicity due to hypermagnesemia.

questions.text: 14. The resident is performing a manoeuvre in the labour room. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure shown is controlled cord traction.

In the third stage of labour, the placenta is expected to be delivered spontaneously soon following the delivery of the baby. If the placenta is not delivered thereafter, it should be delivered forthwith by controlled cord traction (Brandt-Andrews) technique after clamping the cord while the uterus still remains contracted.

In controlled cord traction (modified Brandt-Andrews method), the palmar surface of the fingers of the left hand is placed above the symphysis pubis, approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment. The body of the uterus is pushed upward and backwards, towards the umbilicus, while with the right hand steady tension is given in downward and backwards direction, holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus. The procedure is to be adopted only when the uterus is hard and contracted.

The third stage of labour includes separation, descent, and expulsion of the placenta with its membranes. According to WHO guidelines, active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) has the following components:

* Administration of uterotonics within 1 min of delivery.

* Controlled cord traction and expulsion of the placenta.

* Delayed cord clamping for a minimum of 1-3 minutes to reduce anemia in the fetus.

* Intermittent assessment of the uterine tone for early detection of atony.

questions.text: 15. A P1L1 mother with BMI of 35 diagnosed with pre-eclampsia underwent LSCS. What is the ideal agent for prophylaxis of post partum venous thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
For a P1L1 mother with BMI 35, diagnosed with pre-eclampsia and who underwent LSCS, the risk of postpartum venous thromboembolism (VTE) is high. The ideal agent for prophylaxis in this setting is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH).

Subacutaneous administration of LMWH is used for thromboprophylaxis in immobilized medically ill patients or in those who have undergone major surgery. LMWH is the drug of choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy because it does not cross the placenta to cause fetal malformations. It has better bioavailability, longer half-life, predictable dose response and reduced adverse effects like osteoporosis and thrombocytopenia and less frequent dosing.

For postpartum anticoagulation, LMWH is given subcutaneously once a day for 6-8 weeks. Oral anticoagulants may be considered postpartum based upon planned duration of therapy, lactation and patient preference. 

Other options:

Option B: Although effective for long-term anticoagulation, warfarin is not started immediately after delivery due to the risk of initial hypercoagulability, delayed onset of action, and the need for close INR monitoring.

Option C and D: Clopidogrel and aspirin are antiplatelet drugs, not anticoagulants. It has limited efficacy in preventing venous thromboembolism compared to LMWH.

questions.text: 16. A 28 year old female who was diagnosed with carcinoma cervix presented with hydroureteronephrosis. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma cervix with hydroureteronephrosis is classified as Stage III B  according to Revised 2018 FIGO staging.

Stage III cervical carcinoma may involve the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, may present as hydronephrosis and/or pelvic/paraortic lymph node involvement. It is further staged as follows:

* Stage III A: Lower 1/3rd of the vagina involvement, no pelvic wall extension

* Stage III B: Pelvic wall involvement with or without hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney

* Stage III C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes

* Stage III C1: Metastasis to pelvic lymph node only

* Stage III C2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

Carcinoma cervix can cause ureteral obstruction. Hydronephrosis and uremia can follow and may occasionally be the initial presenting finding. In these cases, ureteral stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy tube insertion is usually required. Kidney function is ideally preserved for chemotherapy.

Pearl PM1903: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

* A: Microscopic lesion

* A1 - stromal invasion ≤3mm depth

* A2 - a stromal invasion of >3 and ≤5mm depth

* B: Macroscopic lesion

* B1 - stromal invasion >5mm depth & tumor size ≤2cm 

* B2 - tumor size >2cm to ≤4cm 

* B3 - tumor size >4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement

* A1 - tumor size ≤4cm 

* A2 - tumor size >4cm 

* B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina

* B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)

* C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent

* C1: pelvic lymph node involved

* C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

* A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)

* B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

Pearl PM2144: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: 17. A 55-year old woman presents with the following finding. She has a history of two home births with an untrained dai. Which of these ligaments could have been injured?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image show uterovaginal prolapse in a 55-year-old woman after two home births assisted by an untrained dhai, and it is most likely due to injury of the Mackenrodt’s (cardinal) ligaments, the chief supports of the uterus.

The descent of one or more of the genital organs below their normal anatomical position is called pelvic organ prolapse (POP). It occurs when the muscles and tissues that support the pelvic organs become weakened or damaged, leading to one or more organs bulging into the vaginal canal. The clinical types are:

1. Vaginal prolapse

a) Anterior vaginal wall: Cystocele in the upper two-third and urethrocele in the lower one-third

b) Posterior vaginal wall: Enterocele in the upper one-third and rectocele in the lower two-third 

2. Uterine descent

The ligaments forming the chief support of the uterus are shown in the image below:



Treatment options may include pessary, pelvic floor exercises, or surgery, depending on the severity of prolapse. The degrees of uterine prolapse is shown in the image below:



Other options:

Option A: Round ligament maintains uterine anteversion but provides no significant pelvic support and not responsible for prolapse.

Option C: Broad ligament is a peritoneal fold and not a primary support of the uterus.

Option D: Inguinal ligament connects the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle, which is unrelated to uterine support.

Pearl PM1349: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: 18. A 45-year-old woman presents with delayed cycles and heavy bleeding for the past year. Ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The next line of management for this patient with an endometrial thickness of 16 mm is an endometrial biopsy. 

In perimenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), the first priority is to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma, since risk increases with age. In this case, ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm. For perimenopausal women, an endometrial thickness >10 mm is generally considered abnormal and requires further evaluation. Therefore, the next best step is an endometrial biopsy to establish a tissue diagnosis.

In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness. If it exceeds 4 mm on ultrasound is considered abnormal and requires histopathological evaluation irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms to rule out endometrial carcinoma or hyperplasia. Immediate endometrial biopsy is indicated rather than waiting and watching or empirical hormonal therapy. Hysterectomy is not the first-line step without a tissue diagnosis. The approach to postmenopausal bleeding is summarised in the flowchart below:



The methods available to obtain endometrial tissue for histopathological examination are:

* Dilation and curettage (D&C) - It is a fractional curettage comprising separate scrapings of endometrium and endocervix not only allows the exact site of malignancy, if present, but also detects the extent of spread of the tumour and staging. It is the best investigation to rule out cancer. The curettage requires general anaesthesia and hospitalization.

* Uterine cavity aspiration for endometrial sampling - It is an outpatient procedure that has the additional advantage of avoiding anaesthesia. Pipelle aspirator or Vibra aspirator is used to obtain endometrial sample. 

* Hysteroscopy with endometrial aspiration

questions.text: 19. A 30-year-old pregnant female with a history of enlarged inguinal lymph nodes and toxoplasmosis 5 years ago tested positive for IgG to toxoplasmosis. She should ____

choices.text: Be counselled that the foetus is at risk of severe infection and pregnancy should be terminated
Be counselled that there is no risk to the foetus and pregnancy can be continued
Undergo amniotic testing to confirm infection to the foetus

questions.solution:
The pregnant female should be counselled that there is no risk to the foetus and that pregnancy can be continued.

This woman’s IgG positivity for toxoplasmosis reflects a past infection, in her case from 5 years ago, and indicates that she has developed long-term immunity and there is no risk for fetal infection. In pregnancy, the concern arises only when a new infection (indicated by IgM positivity) occurs, as that is when Toxoplasma gondii can cross the placenta and infect the fetus. Since her infection happened well before conception, there is no active parasitemia and thus no risk of vertical transmission to the fetus. Therefore, she simply needs reassurance that her pregnancy can continue without specific interventions for toxoplasmosis.

If the current infection is confirmed, the following measures are taken:

* Amniocentesis and cordocentesis for the detection of IgM antibody in the amniotic fluid and fetal blood.

* PCR for T. gondii gene is also done

* Ultrasonography findings suggestive of fetal infection are: ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcification, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, ascites and IUGR at 20-22 weeks

* If the fetus is infected and hydrocephalus is present, counselling for termination is to be done.

Acute toxoplasmosis during pregnancy is treated with Spiramycin (3 g orally daily for 3 weeks), which helps reduce the risk of congenital infection and long-term sequelae. Pyrimethamine-sulfadiazine with leucovorin can be used later in pregnancy (not in the first trimester) for four to six weeks if needed.

questions.text: 20. A 35-year-old lady with amenorrhea presents with galactorrhea. She is diagnosed with pituitary adenoma. What is the most probable cause of the condition?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause of this condition is decrease in GnRH.

In this case, the 35-year-old woman has amenorrhea with galactorrhea, and the underlying cause is a pituitary adenoma, most likely a prolactinoma. The excessive secretion of prolactin in such tumors has a direct inhibitory effect on the hypothalamus. Prolactin inhibits the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone by the hypothalamus. This inhibition, in turn, suppresses the formation of the pituitary gonadotropic hormones - luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone. This pathophysiology is shown in the flowhcart below:



Prolactinoma usually presents with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea. If the tumour extends outside the sella, visual field defects or other mass effects may be seen. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is likely with a prolactin level >200 μg/L. An MRI is recommended in all patients who present with hyperprolactinemia.

Microadenomas can be managed with regular monitoring of prolactin levels and MRI scans, if fertility is not a requisite. Oral dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline are used for medical management. Resistance or intolerance to these drugs requires surgical debulking. Cases that do not respond to medical or surgical management can be treated with radiotherapy.

questions.text: 21. A 46-year old nulliparous woman with a history of irregular periods presents with amenorrhoea for two months and a positive urine pregnancy test. How will you accurately assess the gestational age?
questions.solution:
In early pregnancy, the crown–rump length is the most accurate method for assessing gestational age.

Gestational age refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of the LMP. It is usually expressed in weeks. In case of irregular periods, gestational age calculated with the help of LMP will be inaccurate.

First-trimester ultrasound measurement of CRL is the best method to assess gestational age. It is measured from the outer margin of the cephalic pole to the rump in the midsagittal plane with the embryo or fetus in a neutral, nonflexed position. The embryofetal crown-rump length in the first trimester is accurate up to ± 5 to 7 days. 

CRL measurement is shown in the image below:



The best ultrasonographic parameters for estimation of the gestational age according to the trimester are as follows:

Trimester

Parameter

1st 

Crown-rump length (CRL)

2nd  

Biparietal diameter (BPD)

3rd

 Femur Length. (FL) 


Other parameters like abdominal circumference (AC) and head circumference (HC) can also be used. The following images show the three landmarks used to accurately measure the abdominal circumference:





On TVS, the gestation sac could be seen as early as 4.5-5 weeks. Fetal gestational age can also be estimated by measuring the Mean Gestational Sac Diameter (MSD ), but it is less accurate than CRL and is only used when the embryo is not yet visible.

Pearl PM1827: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

* The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.

* The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.

* Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)

* CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy

* CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.

* The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: 22. A 30-year-old female came with a history of chronic abdominal discomfort for the past 1 year. The MRI shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 30-year-old female with a history of chronic abdominal discomfort for the past 1 year and the MRI showing an enlarged globular uterus with thickening of the junctional zone is suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years. Patients generally present with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, pelvic discomfort, and backache, while some patients are asymptomatic. On examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to a 12-14 week size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination.

TVS findings include alternating vertical stripes of hyperechoic and hypoechoic bands, which is called the Venetian blind appearance. On MRI, a diffuse, widened low-intensity junctional zone ≥12 mm predicts adenomyosis with high accuracy, while a junctional zone ≤8 mm excludes it with high accuracy. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision/Levonorgestrel-containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.



Other options: 

Option A: Fibroid clinically presents similarly to adenomyosis, but fibroid is usually focal, well-circumscribed, the uterus can get more enlarged, and the uterine contour is usually irregular. There is no thickening of the junctional zone as seen in the image.

Option C: Endometrial polyps are overgrowths of benign endometrial stroma covered by columnar epithelium. They appear as smooth polypoid masses arising from the endometrium into the uterine cavity. The USG below shows a characteristic feeding vessel sign on the colour Doppler.



Option D: Endometriosis is the presence of endometrium at a site outside the endometrial lining. It can be found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung. MRI shows haemorrhages, deep pelvic lesions and fibrosis.

questions.text: 23. A G2P1L1 with a history of previous caesarean section presented in active labour. During trial of labour, there was foetal bradycardia and maternal tachycardia. Persistent suprapubic pain between contractions was also noted. On examination, the cervix was 8 cm dilated, and the vertex was at -1 station. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of scar dehiscence, and the next best step in management is emergency LSCS.

The presence of fetal bradycardia, maternal tachycardia, and persistent suprapubic pain between contractions in a woman with a previous caesarean section indicates scar dehiscence which may lead to uterine scar rupture. On examination, the cervix was 8 cm dilated and the vertex at –1 station, meaning the fetal head is still 1 cm above the ischial spines and not yet engaged, making instrumental delivery unsafe. Hence, the next best step is an Emergency Lower Segment Caesarean Section (LSCS) to prevent complete rupture and prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

Uterine rupture is defined as a disruption in the continuity of all the uterine layers (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa) after 20 weeks of pregnancy. It is a potentially life-threatening maternal complication, often associated with an unsuccessful Trial of Labour after Caesarean (TOLAC).

The risk factors of uterine rupture include: 

* More the number (>2) of prior cesarean delivery

* lnterpregnancy interval <24 months

* Induced labor, especially with misoprostol

* Augmentation of labor with high dose oxytocin

* Women having single layer uterine closure in prior cesarean delivery compared to double layer closure

Clinical features include dull abdominal pain over the scar area with slight vaginal bleeding. There are varying degrees of tenderness on uterine palpation. FHS may be irregular or absent. CTG tracings reveal variable or late deceleration (most consistent finding). If the fetal presenting part has already entered the pelvis with labour, loss of station may be detected by pelvic examination. 

To prevent uterine rupture, undue delay in the progress of labor in a multipara with a previous uneventful delivery should be viewed with concern, and the cause should be sought for. Attempted forceps delivery or breech extraction through incompletely dilated cervix should be avoided. The only effective measure to save the fetus is by immediate delivery via emergency LSCS. Following complete rupture during TOLAC, hysterectomy may also be required.
